development, adding 234 dwelling units, including 57 detached single-family dwellings, 73 attached
single-family dwellings (townhouses), and 104 apartment units.

within 500 feet of the project site. On May 19, 2014 an updated notice was
so mailed, and on June 10, 2014 a notice of re-scheduled public hearing also
was so mailed. On June 4, 2014 a public notice was published in the News-

page.text: Lincoln City Municipal Code 17.52.210, Planned Unit Developments

text.i: Criteria

page.text: Lincoln City Municipal Code Chapter 17.16 Single-family Residential (R-1) Zone
Lincoln City Municipal Code Chapter 17.46, Natural Resource Overlay Zone
In 1994 the Planning Commission approved a tentative plan for the Lincoln Palisades Subdivision, a
173-lot single-family development encompassing 71.12 acres of land. The plan, proposed by
Lockhart Investments, which at that time was the property owner, called for the subdivision to be
developed in five phases over a ten-year period. The Planning Commission’s Final Order No. 94-
07 approved the tentative plan with numerous conditions of approval, including dedication to the
city of a large tract of open space. Lockhart Investments transferred the Lincoln Palisades property
to the Cruze Family LLC, which recorded the final plat for the 173-unit subdivision. The Cruze
Family LLC undertook development of part of the property, removing trees, grading the site,
installing streets and utilities, and selling individual lots. This is called Lincoln Palisades Phase 1,
even though it consisted itself of six sub-phases.
In 2005 the Cruze Family LLC transferred the remainder of the Lincoln Palisades property to
Palisades Properties LLC. Phase 2 of Lincoln Palisades was recorded in 2007. Also in 2007
Palisades Properties LLC applied for revised subdivision plan approval, seeking to increase the
number of lots from 173 to 202. All were to be single-family lots. The Planning Commission
approved this proposal in 2007. This is called Lincoln Palisades Phase 3, and again consisted of
several sub-phases. In 2010 Palisades Properties LLC applied for a series of amendments to the
2007 final order. The Planning Commission approved some of the proposed amendments and
denied others. None of the amendments, except as discussed below, are relevant to the present
application.
Now Palisades Properties LLC requests approval of an additional 234 units for Lincoln Palisades.
Rather than applying for a standard subdivision as was done with all the previous applications for
the property, Palisades Properties LLC has applied for Planned Unit Development (PUD) approval.
This was done because in 2011 the city amended the municipal code to require all subdivisions of
more than 10 lots or two acres to be processed as PUDs. Rather than applying for approval solely
of lots for single family dwellings, Palisades Properties LLC seeks approval of 57 detached single-
family dwellings, 73 attached single-family dwellings (townhouses), and 104 apartment units. This
is Lincoln Palisades Phase 3, and again contains another six sub-phases.
The process for consideration of a proposed PUD consists of two major steps. In the first, the
applicant presents a “preliminary master plan” for the proposed development. In the second the
planning commission reviews the “final master plan” for the PUD, or if the PUD is phased, for a
phase of the PUD. In the present matter, the planning commission is focused in the first step, the
review of the preliminary master plan.
The Planning Commission considers the preliminary master plan in a public hearing and
evaluates it against the various criteria of the municipal code. LCMC 17.52.210.L. describes the
planning commission’s authority as follows:
[T]he planning commission shall review the plan and comments in public hearings and
shall give approval, approval with conditions, or disapproval to the preliminary master
plan. The planning commission shall state its decision and its reasons in writing. . . . The
planning commission’s consideration of the preliminary master plan shall be subject to the
following . . . The commission shall approve, or approve with conditions, the plan if it
finds that the plan, either as submitted or with conditions, meets all of the following
criteria. The commission shall disapprove the plan if it finds that the plan, either as
submitted or with conditions, does not meet any one or more of the following criteria.
The Zoning Ordinance allows planned unit developments as a means for “encouraging creative site
planning and building design; to make possible greater diversification between buildings and open
spaces; and to conserve land and minimize development costs” (LCMC 17.52.210.A.). The
Planning Commission may allow deviation from almost all zoning and subdivision standards other
than the type of allowed use, the overall density of the project, and the city-wide 45-foot maximum
height limit.
Permitted Uses in the R-1 Zone. LCMC 17.16.020 lists the allowed uses in the R-1 zone. These
include single-family dwellings, as well as attached single-family dwellings but only in groups of
two. The applicant proposes three uses for the property: single-family dwellings, attached single-
family dwellings (in two, three, and four-unit structures), and multi-family dwellings (apartments).
In the past the Planning Commission has allowed attached single-family dwellings and multi-
family dwellings in several Planned Unit Developments (PUDs) in the R-1 zone. This is based on
the premise that PUDs are intended to allow creativity and diversification and that as long as the
allowed number of dwelling units is not exceeded there should be flexibility in the types of dwelling
units allowed. Staff notes that the words of the Municipal Code are ambiguous on this matter and
that the City Council never has made a formal interpretation on this matter. Staff, nevertheless,
believes that the applicant’s proposed uses are allowed in the R-1-zoned PUD.
Availability of City Services. LCMC 17.16.050 prohibits development in the R-1 zone unless all
city services are available to the site. In this context “city services” means water and sewer service.
This matter is discussed more fully below, but staff has concluded that the required city services are
or will be available at the time of development.
Lot Requirements. LCMC 17.16.070 sets out required minimums for lot size, lot width, lot depth,
and required yards, and maximum lot coverage for standard subdivisions of land. Again because
of the intent of the PUD ordinance to allow flexibility, deviations from these standards, other
than required yards at the perimeter of the proposed development, are allowed.
A Planned Unit Development is a housing development that is not subject to the usual zoning
standards such as lot size and setbacks. Instead the developer establishes the standards for the
project, generally including such things as street widths and architectural design, subject to
approval by the city. According to LCMC 17.52.210.A, the intent of the PUD approach is:
To provide more desirable environments by encouraging creative site planning and
building designs; to make possible greater diversification between buildings and open
spaces; and to conserve land and minimize development costs.
The municipal code contains a set of general criteria that planned unit developments must meet.
Each criterion is printed below in italics followed by staff comments.

i.b: The proposed planned unit development will be substantially compatible with existing
development in the surrounding area; and undeveloped land in the surrounding area
can be developed in a manner substantially compatible with the proposed planned unit
development.

page.text: To approach this criterion, staff interprets “substantially” to mean “mostly” and “compatible” to
mean “capable of existing together without discord or disharmony.” The test then is whether the
proposed PUD will be mostly capable of existing together with present and future development
in the surrounding area without discord or disharmony.
The surrounding area is at least the property within 500 feet of the subject property, as this is the
city’s notification area for public hearings regarding a planned unit development. The
notification area is shown in Figure 1.
This area takes in all or part of the following sites and developments:
• Palisades Condominiums (50 multi-family units)
• Existing single-family lots within Lincoln Palisades (94 lots)
• Vacant land in the county to the west (zoned County R-1-A for single family dwellings)
• Properties on NE Port Lane including those along the east-west leg (8 single-family
homes) and north-south leg (six single-family homes and four undeveloped lots), as well
as properties on NE Port Place and NE 53
rd
Court (10 homes and four lots)
• Proposed Logan Park development along Logan Road (proposed for a mix of single-
family dwellings, townhouses, and apartments)
• Liberty Inn site and adjacent Tribal land
• Pacific Rim Estates (45 single-family homes)
• Beacon Crest apartments (41 multi-family units)
• Devils Lake Golf & Racquet Club Townhouses (seven dwellings and 42 additional lots)
• Maplewood in the Villages at Cascade Head (Block A-prime, approved for 9 duplexes)
• Fernwood in the Villages at Cascade Head (Block A, approved for 200 townhomes,
platted for 60)
• Block B in the Villages at Cascade Head (approved for 184 condominiums)
• Block G in the Villages at Cascade Head (approved for 96 condominiums)
• Block E in the Villages at Cascade Head (approved for 63 single-family homes)
• Various areas of parks, open space, and wetlands in the Villages at Cascade Head
As a practical matter the “surrounding area” extends beyond the 500-foot notice area, and
includes all the property west of NE Devils Lake Blvd. in the Villages at Cascade Head and the
remainder of those properties listed above that are partially within the notice area. Existing
development in the surrounding area consists of single-family homes, a few townhouses,
apartments, and condominiums, as well as a golf course and a motel.
Four factors are useful in determining the proposed development’s compatibility with uses on
surrounding properties. These are (1) the proposed use of the subject property, (2) the proposed
density (units per acre), (3) the proposed lot sizes, and (4) the general style and ambiance of the
proposed development (Traffic impacts also are useful in this regard, and these are discussed
fully in a later section of this staff report.). How the four factors relate to the surrounding area
are as follows:
1) Proposed Use – Development in the surrounding area consists of a mix of single-family
dwellings, duplexes, townhouses, and multi-family housing, plus various areas of parks,
open space, and a golf course. The proposed uses of single-family dwellings,
townhouses, and multi-family dwellings, plus open space, are generally the same kind as
those found in or proposed for the surrounding area. Staff believes that the types of

text.b: uses proposed are substantially compatible with existing development in the

page.text: 2) Proposed Density – The overall density for the proposed project’s six phases is 9.0 units
per acre. According to the applicant, each phase has the following density:
a. Phase 1 (104 apartment units): 10.8 units per acre
b. Phase 2 (40 single-family dwellings): 7.4 units per acre
c. Phase 3 (20 townhouses): 8.6 units per acre
d. Phase 4 (17 single-family dwellings): 4.9 units per acre
e. Phase 5 (18 townhouses): 8.7 units per acre
f. Phase 6 (35 townhouses): 11.7 units per acre

text.b: Figure 1. Map of the Lincoln Palisades area. The green line surrounds the Lincoln Palisades
property and the blue line shows the 500-foot notification area.

page.text: Existing and proposed development in the surrounding area has the following densities.
These densities are the area of the subdivision, including streets, but not associated open
spaces, divided by the number of units.
a. Lincoln Palisades Phase 1 (60 single-family lots): 3.5 units per acre
b. Lincoln Palisades Phase 2 (33 single-family lots): 3.0 units per acre
c. Palisades Condominiums (50 condominiums): 8.5 units per acre
d. Pacific Rim Estates (45 single-family lots): 3.2 units per acre
e. Beacon Crest (41 apartments): 7.8 units per acre
f. Sunridge by the Lake (37 single-family lots): 5.0 units per acre
g. Garden Estates (44 single-family lots): 4.9 units per acre
h. Compass Point (17 single-family lots): 4.3 units per acre
i. Maplewood Village (18 duplex units): 4.9 units per acre
j. Fernwood Village (60 townhouse lots): 4.8 units per acre
k. Villages at Cascade Head Block B (184 condominium units): 7.8 units per acre
l. Villages at Cascade Head Block E (63 single-family lots): 2.7 units per acre
m. Villages at Cascade Head Block G (96 condominiums): 7.7 units per acre
Based on these figures, it is apparent that the overall density of the proposed project is
higher than that of the surrounding developments. In particular, the 10.8 apartment units
per acre of Phase 1 and the 11.7 townhouse units per acre of Phase 6 are high compared
to the surrounding development as a whole and even high compared to the surrounding
multi-family and townhouse developments. Also, the existing parts of the Lincoln
Palisades development and the nearby Pacific Rim Estates are among the lowest density
developments in the City. Staff believes the high density proposed is inconsistent

text.b: with the density of development in the surrounding area.

page.text: 3) Proposed Lot Sizes – In the R-1-7.5 zoning district, the minimum lot size is 7,500 square
feet. The PUD may vary this standard as long as it does not exceed the overall allowed
density. The proposed preliminary master plan does not provide a listing of the proposed
lot sizes for the development’s single-family lots, but most of the lots clearly are smaller
than the normal minimum for the zone. Examination of the application materials shows
that the proposed single family lots in the preliminary master plan appear to be in the
4,000 to 5,000 square foot range. In contrast, Lincoln Palisades Phases 1 and 2 were
straight subdivisions that met the minimum lot size for the R-1-7.5 zone and are 8,000
square feet or larger. See Figure 2. The preliminary master plan’s single-family lots also
are substantially smaller than the single-family lots in surrounding developments.
In most cases the proposed development lines both sides of new or extended streets.
Thus the new development would adjoin existing development only on the rear lot lines.
However, NE Voyage Way and NE Wave Lane are different. In those cases the new
development would be immediately across the street from the existing development. The
existing lots on the west side of these streets are between 8,000 and 9,000 square feet and
are over 70 feet in width. In contrast the proposed lots on the east sides of these streets
are between 4,000 and 5,000 square feet and about 46 feet in width. The distinctly
different lot sizes on opposite sides of the streets makes for an incongruent streetscape.

text.b: Figure 2. Map showing relationships of proposed and existing lot sizes and building sizes..
Staff believes the small lots on the east sides of NE Voyage Way and NE Wave Lane
are incompatible with the existing development of the west sides of those streets.

page.text: One possible way to address this incompatibility would be to include some larger lots on
the east side similar to the west side to provide more balance. Another possibility would
be to utilize uneven duplexes or the “big house” concept proposed for the nearby Logan
Park development that have more than one unit in a building that appears to be a single-
family home.
4) Appearance and Ambiance – In order to avoid discord or disharmony a proposed
development should be designed to incorporate the feel or mood of the area in which it is
placed. In this context it is useful to recall that one of the intents of the PUD approach is
to encourage creative site planning and building design, and that among the aims of
creative site design is to preserve existing trees.
Trees. In much of the area covered by the preliminary master plan the Cruze Family
LLC, the original developer, stripped off most of the mature trees several years ago,
before the present owner acquired the property. This is particularly true with respect to
the areas designated in the preliminary master plan as Phases 3, 4, and 6, and most of
Phase 2. The original developer did leave some mature Sitka spruces (about a dozen) in
the areas originally developed. The original developer also left the areas of proposed
Phases 1 and 5 and a small portion of Phase 2 largely undisturbed. Existing
developments in the surrounding area outside Lincoln Palisades, at least to the south,
similarly were accomplished on land that had been fully cleared. These include the
Pacific Rim Estates, Sunridge by the Lake, and Garden Estates subdivisions and the
Beacon Crest apartment complex. The property owner immediately to the west of the
southern-most portion of Lincoln Palisades likewise clear-cut his land a couple of years
ago, although that property has not been developed.
Land to the west of the northern-most portion of the proposed development is fully
forested vacant land. In contrast to the existing portions of the Lincoln Palisades
development and surrounding development to the south, development and proposed
development to the north and east, including the Palisades Condominiums and the
Villages at Cascade Head properties, have focused on preserving trees and siting
buildings and infrastructure so as to minimize the removal of trees, especially mature
Sitka spruces. These developments can be characterized as being built among the trees
rather than having all or most of the trees removed for development.
The preliminary master plan for this development includes a tree tagging report that
identifies 1,476 trees that have diameters of six inches or more within the boundaries of
the plan. The majority of these are within Phase 1. The plan calls for the removal of
almost all of them, excepting those in a few areas on the perimeter of Phase 1. Of the 57
trees identified as having diameters of 36 inches or more in Phase 1 (all of them Sitka
spruces), only 14 are called out as being preserved; the other 43 are to be removed. All
but one of the 14 large trees designated for preservation are on the north and west edges
of the development. Ten of them are shown with a road within their drip lines and over
their roots, raising the question of how practical preservation of these trees will be given
that the road will require grading and fill and that Sitka spruces typically have shallow
root systems that would be damaged by these activities.
The city retained the services of Trout Mountain Forestry, a consulting forester, to
examine the condition of trees within the project boundary and to review the tree
inventory and tree protection plan. Trout Mountain’s letter report is attached to this staff
report. The Trout Mountain forester found the tree inventory to be thorough and detailed,
but noted that it identified only two trees for preservation, neither of which is located on
the applicant’s property.
The forester also noted that the tree inventory says there are some trees actually on the
applicant’s property that do merit protection but does not identify the specific trees or
explain why they should be protected. He concluded that this shortcoming means there is
no way of determining to what extent the development plans make adequate provision for
protecting trees as required under the intent of tree ordinance (LCMC 17.52.220 provides
that the intent of the tree removal and protection provisions of the code is to protect trees
where appropriate, including through taking reasonable measures in development to
avoid tree removal. The section provides further that the burden of proof is on the
applicant to show that tree removal is necessary, and that other alternatives are not
feasible.).
The forester criticized what he saw as inadequate buffering of some larger trees along
roads and paths where earth-moving development will occur. He also criticized the
applicant’s plans for tree removal in Phase 1. He noted that the site poses little evidence
of wind damage to trees and that he saw no evidence of site planning that was intended to
preserve the large, low-risk Sitka spruces on the site. The forester summarized his report
as follows:
I find the applicant fails to justify the widespread removal of trees from the site.
The Planning Department should request the applicant provide a more sensitive
development plan, and more robust arborist’s report and tree protection plan to
more fully comply with the intent of City tree protection and development
ordinances. A proposal of the scope and intensity requires careful scrutiny to
protect the site’s significant aesthetic and natural resources.
Based on their own observations, and those of the consulting forester, staff has concluded
that the PUD proposal includes little in the way of creative site planning to enable tree
preservation that would positively affect the ambiance of the development. What is
proposed is a complete removal of trees in the areas to be developed, which is surrounded
by a thin fringe of trees whose survival is suspect. In the area where the impacts of the
tree removal will be greatest, adjacent to the Palisades Condominiums, even this fringe is
missing. Staff believes that this aspect of this criterion is not satisfied.
Building Design. The preliminary master plan does not provide any information on the
design of the single-family dwellings and the townhouses. Existing single-family
dwellings within Lincoln Palisades generally are one and two story homes of attractive
suburban design. Since there is no information on the design of the houses proposed for
Phases 2 and 4 (the phases consisting of single-family lots) it is not possible to draw any
conclusions about their compatibility with surrounding development.
Similarly there is no information in the preliminary master plan on the design of the
townhouses proposed for Phases 3, 5, and 6. Because of this lack of information it is not
possible to draw any conclusions about their compatibility with surrounding
development.
The master plan does include floor plans and some elevations for the apartments
proposed for Phase 1. The facades of the apartments could best be described as a
variation on classical or colonial styles. In contrast, the adjacent Palisades
Condominiums and the preliminary plans for the Villages at Cascade Head to the east are
more in the Pacific Northwest style.

text.b: Figure 3-a. Concept elevation from applicant’s Phase 1 master plan.
Figure 3-b. Concept study in Pacific Northwest style.

page.text: The inharmonious design of the apartment buildings, coupled with the lack of
information on the design of the townhouses and single family dwellings, make it

text.b: impossible to conclude that the building design is substantially compatible with
existing development in the surrounding area.

page.text: Conclusion. Staff concludes that the combination of the higher density development, the
smaller lot sizes, and especially the too-dense agglomeration of stylistically inharmonious
apartments on what will be a treeless site renders the proposed development incompatible
with the existing and planned surrounding developments.

i.b: The number of years proposed for completion of the development or each phase of the
development is reasonable taking into consideration the possibility of changing land use
patterns in or requirements of the City over time. In order to ensure that the
development will be compatible with land use patterns in and requirements of the city at
the time of approval of a final master plan, the planning commission shall establish an
expiration date for the preliminary master plan approval, not sooner than two years after
approval of the preliminary master plan; may impose conditions requiring that a final
master plan or phases thereof be submitted for commission review within a specified
period or periods of time, not sooner than one year after approval of the preliminary
master plan; or may impose conditions requiring commission reevaluation of as yet
unbuilt portions of the development, for conformity with then-existing city zoning
ordinance requirements in relation to then-existing conditions, not sooner than five
years after approval of the preliminary master plan, and at such periodic intervals of not
less than five years thereafter as the commission deems appropriate to ensure
conformity.

page.text: The applicant proposes to develop this project in six phases with two years between phases.
The phasing is a follows:
Phase 1: 2014-2015, 104 apartment units;
Phase 2: 2016-2017, 40 single family dwellings;
Phase 3: 2018-2019, 20 townhouses;
Phase 4: 2020-2021, 17 single family dwellings;
Phase 5: 2022-2023, 18 townhouses;
Phase 6: 2024-2025, 35 townhouses.
At this schedule, after the apartments are started the sites for single-family homes and
townhouses would become available at an average rate of 13 units per year. It is likely that
build-out of the phases would overlap due to a relatively low absorption rate for new
houses. Nevertheless, the schedule, while probably rather optimistic, probably is
reasonable. Therefore this criterion is met.
LCMC 17.52.210.L.1.b. also requires the Planning Commission to set an expiration date
for the preliminary master plan approval, not sooner than two years after approval of the
preliminary master plan. Staff suggests that two years is a reasonable period for such
approval to expire, subject to one two-year extension at the discretion of the Planning
Commission. Additionally, staff suggests setting deadlines for obtaining approval for final
master plans for each of the various phases. The applicant has suggested two years
between phases, and staff suggests that this be the requirement. Staff has included a
recommended condition of approval to that effect.

i.b: Construction of the development can be accomplished in a manner that does not create
unreasonable negative impacts on the area surrounding the development or in the city.
In order to assure the avoidance or mitigation of negative construction impacts on the
area surrounding the development or in the city, the planning commission may impose
conditions including but not limited to:
i.
Requirements that removal of existing landscaping during construction
be limited to areas of the planned unit development to be constructed
shortly following removal and to portions of those areas on which
construction will occur;
ii.
Prohibitions of open burning on the site during construction;
iii.
Prohibitions or limitations on construction track-out;
iv.
Restrictions on construction noise; and
v.
Restrictions on construction traffic.

page.text: This criterion addresses the impacts to the surrounding area from the construction activities
related to the proposed development. Typically such impacts have included noise, smoke,
track-out of mud, and traffic. The applicant will be required to comply with the City’s
noise control ordinance limiting noise to be produced, especially between the hours of 7
p.m. and 7 a.m. This has been made a recommended condition of approval.
Grading and filling can have adverse impacts on properties in close proximity. In order to
help minimize these, staff has drafted a condition of approval that restricts grading and
filing activities, other than those associated with the construction of individual buildings, to
one phase of the development at a time.
Likewise the applicant must not allow open burning on the site. This has been made a
recommended condition of approval as well. The project is subject to erosion control
measures that will reduce potential negative impacts to adjacent properties and the wetland
area in the east side of the project...
Construction traffic and daytime noise may have some impact on the surrounding
properties, but is not an unreasonable burden, as these potential impacts would be part of
any residential development project on this site. Staff has drafted a limit on the hours of
truck traffic, identical to the limit on noise in order to decrease negative impacts on the
surrounding property or the City.
Construction traffic should attempt to minimize dirt, mud, and gravel track out from the
site as much as possible. To accomplish this the applicant should set up wash-down areas
for construction equipment at the entrance to any area where construction traffic may enter
public streets. Staff has recommended this as a condition of approval (see condition 17).
In order to minimize the amount of Phase 1 construction traffic through existing residential
neighborhoods, during the development of that phase construction vehicles should use
West Devils Lake Boulevard to reach the construction site. This will require the applicant
to construct the connection from the current end of Voyage Avenue in Lincoln Palisades to
its connection with the stub of Voyage Avenue in the Villages at Cascade Head property
before any work is done on the . This has been made a condition of approval.

text.b: Staff concludes that with these restrictions this criterion will be met.

i.b: The development will not create unreasonable negative impacts on the area surrounding
the development or in the city. In order to assure the avoidance or mitigation of negative
impacts, the planning commission may require the filing of restrictions in the county
deed records including but not limited to restrictions:
i.
Prohibiting the removal of specified landscaping; and
ii.
Prohibiting open burning during construction.

page.text: This criterion addresses the impacts of the development itself, as opposed to the
construction of the development addressed in the previous criterion.
The principal negative impacts from the proposed development will fall on the Palisades
Condominiums. This development will lose the buffer of trees to its north, and instead of a
forest view the residents will have a view of apartment buildings. Some redesign of the
project, especially with respect to creative site design to foster retention of trees could
reduce this impact. The matter of tree removal has been discussed above, and the same
discussion is applicable here. In staff’s opinion, the impacts on the Palisades

text.b: Condominiums, given the apparent failure to use creative design opportunities to
reduce impacts on surrounding properties, are unreasonable.

page.text: There also will be impacts on the local off-site road network, particularly but not
exclusively Port Lane. The impacts on NE Port Lane are described below and will not be
repeated here, but instead are incorporated by reference. In a nutshell, staff expects that
traffic on NE Port Lane will double. This narrow street already is relatively dangerous

text.b: and a traffic increase of that magnitude, without mitigation, will be unreasonable.

page.text: There will be additional impacts on properties adjacent to NE Voyage Avenue, NE 47
th
Street, and NE Devils Lake Blvd. from increased traffic to and from the proposed
dwellings.

text.b: In staff’s opinion, this criterion is not met.

i.b: Street, water, sewer, drainage and drainage pre-treatment, storm water detention, and
other similar facilities in the area surrounding the development and in the City are or
will be adequate to provide for the health, safety, and welfare for the development’s
population densities and the type of development proposed, taking into consideration
existing and projected future demands on those facilities.

page.text: This criterion’s intent is for the Commission to evaluate all facilities and conditions in the
area surrounding the proposed development and to make a determination if they are
adequate to provide for the proposal and future growth in the area. Staff has provided the
following response to these items:
1) Streets- The applicant has obtained a traffic impact analysis (TIA) that has determined
that intersections in the area will continue to provide acceptable levels of service (LOS)
with this portion of Lincoln Palisades being built out. The city retained DKS Associates,
a transportation planning and engineering firm, to evaluate the TIA. The report from
DKS is attached to this staff report. As a result of the DKS evaluation and staff’s own
review of the TIA, staff has concluded that the applicant’s TIA is flawed and does
not give an accurate assessment of the project’s traffic impacts for the reasons
described below.
a. Port Lane. The TIA excludes Port Lane from its analysis because, according to the
report, the development will result in only 20 peak hour trips. Instead most traffic is
assumed to use Voyage Avenue, 47th Street and West Devils Lake Boulevard rather than
Port Lane and Logan Road. This is incorrect. Residents of the existing parts of Lincoln
Palisades, and others, today use Port Lane a shortcut. When going to the commercial
centers on Logan Road, to the beach in Roads End, and to points south on Highway 101
the Port Lane/Logan Road route is substantially shorter than the Voyage Avenue/47th
Street/West Devils Lake Road route, which also requires two stops and out-of-direction
travel. According to the DKS report,
While residences south of NE Port Lane (generally Phases 3, 4 and 6) are likely to
use the NE Voyage Avenue/NE 47th Street/NE West Devils Lake Road route,
most residents north of NE Port Lane (generally Phases 1, 2 and 5) not heading
north on US 101 or south on NE West Devils Lake Road are likely to use NE Port
Lane. Assuming Phases 1, 2 and 5 would use NE Port Lane to go south into
Lincoln City or to the Logan Road commercial area, would result in roughly 50-
60 percent of the site trips using NE Port Lane/Logan Road, which is significantly
higher than the 10 percent assumed in the study. Assuming 50 percent of traffic
from the site (Phases 1, 2 and 5) use NE Port Lane, existing volumes on NE Port
Lane would increase by about 1,000 vehicles daily, which would likely result in
additional livability concerns by residents of NE Port Lane. [Emphasis added]
The TIA fails to consider these additional trips, to assess their impact, and to recommend
any needed mitigation measures. For example, the DKS evaluation noted that to the
extent the increased traffic on Port Lane goes to the Logan Road/Highway 101
intersection, this traffic could push the intersection over the generally accepted ratio of
vehicles to capacity. This is not addressed in the TIA. Neither are the increased traffic’s
possible impacts on left turn queuing on Logan Road at Highway 101.
Another effect of the increased traffic on Port Lane would be a reduced increase in traffic
on Voyage Avenue and West Devils Lake Boulevard compared to what the TIA predicts.
The volume-to-capacity ratio could be positively affected for the intersection of West
Devils Lake Boulevard and Highway 101. This needs to be assessed as well as the
negative effects at Logan Road.
b. Impact Amelioration. The applicant’s TIA asserts that certain projects listed in the
city’s draft (unadopted) Transportation System Plan (TSP) will ameliorate the impacts of
the development. These are:
o
US 101/NE West Devils Lake Road - widen to five lanes
o
US 101/Logan Road – add a 2
nd
northeast-bound left-turn lane; reconfigure
southbound Logan Road to allow right-turns from middle lane
o
Extend NE 47
th
Street to the intersection of NW 44
th
Street/Logan Road
However, since the TSP currently is only a draft, none of the listed projects are in an
adopted plan. Likewise, in contrast to the old draft plan the applicant’s consultant relied
on, the current version of the draft plan finds that there is no reasonable expectation that
the listed projects will be funded in the next 20 years. Thus no amelioration can be
expected from these projects. This part of this criterion is not met.
Final Order No. 07-22 required applicant to pay $250,000.00 to repair/improve NE Devils
Lake Blvd. In the time since that final order was adopted the justification for the $250,000
has changed because the City repaired the road with overlay funds. However the road is still
in only in fair condition; also this road is lacking in pedestrian facilities and is designated as
part of the Head to Bay trail system.
2) Water- The Site is served by City water. In Final Order No. 07-22, an order approving an
earlier iteration of this project, the applicant was required to upgrade the Port Lane water
booster station with, at a minimum, an on-site generator designed to provide continued
service for domestic and fire flows during power outage events. The applicant did not act on
this approval and did not construct the upgrade to Port Lane water booster station.
In 2008/09 the City designed and constructed a new Port Lane booster station as part of a
larger project - the Roads End Reservoir Upgrade Project. The upgrade to the Port Lane
booster pump station was intended to improve service to existing customers and to provide
increased capacity for use by anticipated future development including Lincoln Palisades.
Water service in area is now adequate to support the proposed development.
Lincoln Palisades must pay its proportionate share of the costs of the water booster station
upgrade. Since the new Port Lane water booster station was designed and constructed as
part of a larger project, the proportionate share of its costs is determined based only on the
part of the actual construction cost of the work directly associated with the booster pump
station. The Public Works Department has determined the costs associated with the Port
Lane water booster station to be $578,521.00. The Port Lane water booster pump station
currently serves 507 existing or approved dwelling units. Lincoln Palisades Phase 3 is
proposed to have 234 units. With its increase in capacity the booster pump station
potentially could serve 146 units in addition to Lincoln Palisades Phase 3 (Logan Park at 71
proposed units, Rosso at 50 units, and the Confederated Tribes of Siletz Indians 25 units).
Thus the booster pump station potentially serves a total 887 units. Based on those figures,
Lincoln Palisades Phase 3’s proportionate share of the water booster pump station is:
$152,620.00. Staff has included a condition of approval requiring the applicant to pay that
amount. With that this part of this criterion will be met.
3) Sewer- The site will have access to City sewer lines. But the sewer lift station serving the
site, known as the West Devils Lake Road pump station, presently is at capacity and is
inadequate to serve the proposed development. The city’s Urban Renewal Agency is
preparing to upgrade this pump station.
The applicant will be required to contribute its proportionate share of the upgrade of the
West Devils Lake Road pump station. The exact amount of contribution cannot be
determined at this time, but it will be based on a percentage of the flows contributed by
the Lincoln Palisades Phase 3 project relative to the upgraded capacity of the station. The
engineering report, plans and specifications for the upgrade have been completed. The
Urban Renewal Agency expects to award the contract for construction of the upgrade this
month.
The Public Works Department used the pre-design report prepared by HBH Consulting
Engineering dated April 17, 2014 to determine what percentage of flow Lincoln Palisades
Phase 3 will contribute. The analysis concluded that Phase 3 flows will be 12.56 % of
the full build out for the contributing area. Therefore Lincoln Palisades is required to
contribute 12.56% of the final engineering and construction cost of the pump station. The
final costs will be known once the project is complete, scheduled for October 2014. No
additional flows will be allowed to be connected to the existing pump station until the
upgrade project is completed and accepted by the city. While the city is planning to move
forward with this project, there are no guarantees that the needed capacity will be there
until the upgrade project is fully completed and in service. If the upgrade project is

text.b: successfully completed, this part of this criterion will be met. If for some reason it is
not completed this part of this criterion will not be met.

page.text: 4) Drainage, Drainage Pre-Treatment, and Storm water Detention- The drainage basin in
which most of Lincoln Palisades is located drains to Devils Lake through an un-named
creek that flows through wetlands along much of its length. These wetlands are shown
on the city’s Natural Resource Overlay Zone maps as significant wetlands. Staff is
unaware of any problems with this drainage way.
The remainder of the project, principally the western part of Phase 1, drains to the west
into Logan Creek in Roads End. This drainage also flows through a significant wetland.
Because of a constriction in the drainage from Logan Creek to the ocean, during heavy or
prolonged rains the drainage is inadequate and often floods Sal-La-Sea Road and adjacent
properties. As yet the flooding has not caused any damage to property improvements, but
any substantial increase in flows to this creek are likely to result in increased flooding.
LCMC 17.46.040.B. prohibits activities that would alter the hydrology of a significant
wetland, or that would introduce sediment or lead to erosion. The applicant must create
an onsite detention system that will maintain pre-development water flow from the site.
In other words, though upon development there will be much more impervious surface
than currently exists, the applicant must not discharge water from the site at a faster rate
than occurs in its pre-developed state. This requires the developer to provide areas within
the development that store water during storms and then release it at a rate no greater that
the pre-development rate.
The applicant has proposed a system of surface detention and treatment facilities. The
City Engineer has conducted a preliminary review of them and expects that they will be
adequate. The city engineer will make a more detailed review of these facilities as a part
of the review of any final master plans. Staff has determined that because the developer
has the capability, through the engineering of on-site detention, to avoid adding
additional flooding to the surrounding area, and is required to do so, this part of this

i.b: 6. Street, water, sewer, drainage and drainage pre-treatment, storm water detention and
other similar facilities proposed to be constructed as part of the development are
adequate to provide for the health, safety and welfare for the population densities and
the type of the development proposed.

page.text: This criterion addresses the adequacy of on-site facilities.
1) Streets- The proposed streets appear to be adequate with respect to capacity. There are
other issues with respect to the internal streets, however. The first concerns what the
plans call out as NE Crest Court in Phase 4 in the southern part of the project. The plans
show this street ending in a cul-de-sac. The plans the applicant submitted in 2007, and
those the former property owner submitted, showed this road as a loop. In fact the former
property owner constructed a stub off of Voyage Avenue for the southern end of the loop.
In the site plan review meeting the engineer representing the applicant said the loop was
impractical due to slope issues. Staff notes that in 2007 the same engineer put forward
plans that showed the loop apparently being practical. It is unclear what has changed
since that engineer, and the former owner’s engineer, proposed the loop. What is
apparent is that the cul-de-sac is proposed for a site that has over 20 feet of drop across
the cul-de-sac’s diameter. This would require either a 25 percent slope across the cul-de-
sac or extensive grading to lessen the slope, possibly undermining adjacent properties.
Also of concern is the connection between NE 55
th
Lane in Phase 6 and NE 55
th
Place in
Phase 3. This road also involves substantial topographical issues, crossing a ravine with
40 to 50 feet of depth. At the bottom of the ravine is a significant wetland. While
extensive filling of the ravine might make the connection feasible for most of its length,
the significant wetland may not be filled and may not be crossed with a culvert. Instead
only a bridge entirely outside of the wetland is allowed. The applicant’s plans do not
indicate how the road is to be constructed and how the wetland is to be crossed. There is
a short 50-foot break in the continuity of the wetland and the plans show the road going
through that break. Given that the break is at the bottom of the deep ravine makes staff
doubt the practicality of using that break as a roadway. The applicant may be able to
demonstrate how this can be done, but if this does not happen, the connection would have
to be eliminated from the plans.
Eliminating the connection will have significant effects on the design of the project.
LCMC 16.12.100 limits cul-de-sacs to no more than 600 feet in length and allows them
to serve no more than 18 single-family dwellings. The plans show 36 attached single-
family dwellings abutting NE 51
st
Lane, and 21 dwellings abutting NE 55
th
Place. Each
would have to be reduced to 18 dwellings if the road connection is not practicable. This
has been made a condition of approval.
2) Water- With the completion of the Roads End water pump station mentioned earlier,
water pressures are expected to be adequate for the proposed development. The
applicant’s plans show generally where water lines will be placed and staff has no
concerns in that regard. The North Lincoln Fire and Rescue District fire marshal has
reviewed the proposal. The fire district also will have input on the final number and
location of fire hydrants. This has been made a condition of approval.
3) Sewer- The applicant has provided approximate locations of proposed sewer lines for the
interior of the project. As individual lots develop, they will be able to utilize these lines.
Detailed depictions of water and sewer facilities will be required to be approved by the
City engineer prior to approval of any final master plans and final subdivision plats. The
plans call out grinder pump stations at various locations and the city engineer will have to
determine their practicality before they are allowed.
4) Drainage, Drainage Pre-treatment, and Storm water Detention - The applicant’s plans
show the locations of drainage and drainage pre-treatment facilities in a general way.
They do not show the capacities of the facilities and at this stage staff is unable to say
whether they are adequate or able to be made adequate given the topography of the site
and the amount of drainage that will have to be handled. The final plans for drainage,
drainage pre-treatment
, and discharge
will need to be to city standards and reviewed by
the City Engineer prior to Final Master Plan and the Final Subdivision Plat approval.

i.b: The proposed number of residential units does not exceed the maximum permitted
number of residential units; and at least 15 percent of the gross area is dedicated to
landscaping.

page.text: The applicant provided a detailed description of how it calculated the permitted number of units,
which it determined to be 234 units. The applicant took advantage of five density bonuses allowed
for a PUD to arrive at that number. Before discussing them, however, a threshold matter must be
addressed. This matter is that status of what is shown on the applicant’s plans as “Tract A” and
which the applicant proposes to be set aside as open space. Staff’s analysis leads to the conclusion
that at least 17.88 acres of the proposed site, most or all of which is in the proposed open space area,
is not available to be counted for density calculation purposes. Staff’s reasoning follows.
In 1994, Lockhart Investments, then the owner of the Lincoln Palisades property, obtained approval
for a 173-unit subdivision. The tentative plat showed various lots including one numbered 72, with
Water must pass through an approved water quality control device prior to discharge.
Water discharged onto adjacent properties, including wetlands must pass through a flow spreader.
an area of about 5,250 square feet, and another numbered 122, with an area of 779,145 square feet
(17.88 acres). The final order approving the tentative plat for the subdivision said this about those
two lots:
Lots 72 and 122 have been designated open space areas on the Lincoln Palisades
Tentative Plan. The storm drainage detention facility will occupy Lot 72. The subdivider
has offered to designate lots 72 and 122 as open spaces areas to be dedicated to the city
for use for parks and open space purposes. While such dedication is consistent with the
overall philosophy of the parks master plan encouraging trails and open space systems,
the Lincoln City Parks Master Plan does not call for an open space of this size in this
area. Accordingly, the city would accept deed of dedication of this area to the city, with a
reversionary clause if the city did not continue to use the lots for parks or open space
purposes, or public purposes, but such dedication would not provide a credit against the
systems development charges ultimately to be imposed on the development for park
purposes.
This deed of dedication shall be filed and executed with the final plat map for lot 72
under the Phase 3 portion of the proposed development as currently depicted on the
tentative map, and for lot 122 under the Phase 4 portion of the tentative map.
Lockhart Investments LLC did not ever file a final plat map for any part of Lincoln Palisades.
Instead the company transferred the property to the Cruze Family LLC, with Ty Cruze as manager.
In 1996 the Cruze Family LLC recorded the initial plat of Lincoln Palisades. The plat shows 60
building lots (but not Lot 72), plus two large remainder lots, Tract 61 and Tract 62. Tract 61
consists of the unsubdivided portion of the overall Lincoln Palisades property located east of
Voyage Avenue. Tract 62 is the parcel west of Voyage Avenue and north of the Palisades
Condominiums. The plat contains the following note:
Tracts 61 and 62 are subject to future subdivision platting, and portions of tracts 61 and 62
will be designated at that time as open spaces to be dedicated to the City of Lincoln City for
public use and maintenance.
Thus with the first platting of Lincoln Palisades the property owner committed to putting aside some
of the property, as open space, not to be developed, in accordance with the terms of the final order
approving the subdivision.
Later the property changed hands again, with the present applicant taking control of it. In 2009
the present applicant filed for a series of amendments to the 1994 and 2007 orders, including a
change to the open space dedication requirement. The Planning Commission approved some of
the proposed amendments, but not others. With regard to the open space dedication requirement,
the result was to change the last paragraph of the open space dedication condition to read,
The applicant shall file and execute the deed of dedication of the open space with the final
plat map for Phase 3 of Lincoln Palisades. In the event the applicant does not submit the

text.i: final plat of Phase 3 before June 28, 2012, then at that time the applicant must provide the

page.text: deed of dedication. [Emphasis added]
The applicant did not submit the final plat before June 28, 2012. Therefore the deed of
dedication was due at that time. The applicant has not provided the deed of dedication.
Accordingly the applicant is in violation of the 2010 order. But violation aside, the 2010
dedication requirement raises the issue of whether the applicant is entitled to count the open
space area at all in calculating the allowed density, since the applicant should have deeded it to
the city two years ago. Staff believes that the orders are clear on their faces and the dedication
was required, making the open space area unavailable, since allowing it to be counted would be
rewarding the applicant for violating the earlier order. The applicant disagrees with this
conclusion and asserts that it should be allowed to count to open space area.
If one excludes the 17.88 acres (778,853 square feet) of open space area, then the gross square
footage of the Lincoln Palisades property is reduced from 1,977.399 square feet to 1,198,546
square feet. Multiplying this number by 0.83, as required by the zoning ordinance to account for
streets and sidewalks, the final net residential area is 994,793 square feet. Dividing this figure by
7,500 (the minimum lot size in the R-1-7.5 zone) the maximum base residential density then is
reduced from 204 to 132 units.
This matter has implications beyond the maximum base residential density. The applicant took
advantage of the following density bonuses allowed for a PUD:
• Steep slopes: 2 unit bonus;
• Energy efficiency: 4 units;
• Outdoor water conservation: 2 units;
• Indoor water conservation: 2 units;
• Tree preservation: 20 units.
These bonuses are calculated as a percentage of the maximum base residential density. With the
drop from 204 to 132 units, the bonuses also would drop. Thus instead of a ten-unit increase for the
first four bonuses (the tree preservation bonus is set aside for the moment) there would be a bonus
of six units.
Turning to the “tree preservation” density bonus, with the information available in the application,
staff is unable to calculate the applicable tree preservation bonus, if any. With what information is
available, it appears that the tree preservation bonus could be as high as 13 units.
Disregarding the issue of whether it is proper to count the area of the open space in calculating the
allowed density, staff notes that in the application the applicant made an error in calculating the tree
preservation bonus. In the calculations for this bonus the applicant properly first subtracted the
areas of steep slopes, drainage ways, and wetlands (for which no bonus is available), but then added
them back in when identifying the amount of the site that would remain under the existing tree
canopy. As a result the applicant has overstated the amount of tree canopy to remain. Instead of 54
percent of the site remaining under the tree canopy, only 16.6 percent would so remain. This would
entitle the applicant to an eight percent density bonus, rather than ten percent. Instead of a 20 unit
bonus the applicant would be entitled to 16 units. The maximum number of allowed units would
have to be reduced accordingly.
Conclusion. There is a substantial issue regarding whether the applicant is entitled to count to open
space area in calculating the maximum base residential density, and in calculating the allowed
density bonuses. The applicant has calculated the allowed number of dwelling units as 234 units,
which in any event should be reduced to 230 units because of a calculation error. Excluding the
open space area would result in the allowed number of units being reduced to a total of not more
than 151 units. However, given the fact that there is a disagreement over the applicability of the
dedication requirement from the earlier orders, the Planning Commission may wish to allow the
open space area to be counted for the purposes of the maximum base residential density, but to
disallow it for the purposes of calculating bonuses and thereby reduce the total number of allowed
units to 210.
The applicant proposes a Preliminary Master Plan for the remainder of the Lincoln Palisades
development, adding 234 dwelling units, including 57 detached single-family dwellings, 73 attached
single-family dwellings (townhouses), and 104 apartment units.
In order to approve the application the Planning Commission must find the following:
1. That the proposed PUD will be substantially compatible with existing development in
the surrounding area. In this regard staff has concluded that the types of uses proposed
are substantially compatible with existing development in the surrounding area, but that
the proposed density overall and the lot sizes proposed specifically for the east sides of
NE Voyage Way and NE Wave Lane are not so compatible. Similarly, staff believes the
proposal to almost completely remove all trees from the proposed development is not
substantially compatible with the existing development patterns in the surrounding area.
Staff further believes the design of the proposed buildings, insofar as it is known, is not
substantially compatible with that of development in the surrounding area.
2. That the number of years proposed for completion of the development or each phase is
reasonable. In this regard staff has concluded that the proposed schedule allowing two
years between phases is reasonable and this criterion is met.
3. That construction of the development can be accomplished in a manner that does not

text.i: create unreasonable negative impacts on the area surrounding the development or in

page.text: the city. Staff has concluded that with standard restrictions this criterion will be met.
4. That the development will not create unreasonable negative impacts on the area
surrounding the development or in the city. Staff has concluded that the proposed
development will have unreasonable negative impacts on abutting development, both
existing and proposed, through excessive tree removal and through traffic impacts on
streets in the surrounding area.
5. That street, water, sewer, drainage and drainage pre-treatment, storm water detention,

text.i: and other similar facilities in the area surrounding the development and in the City are

page.text: or will be adequate. With respect to streets, staff has concluded that the applicant’s
traffic impact analysis is fatally flawed. Accordingly this criterion is not met. With
respect to the other facilities this criterion can be met.
6. That street, water, sewer, drainage and drainage pre-treatment, storm water detention,

text.i: and other similar facilities proposed to be constructed as a part of the development are

page.text: adequate. Staff has concluded that these facilities will be adequate. The one caveat is
that the connection shown between NE 55
th
Lane and NE 55
th
Place may not be
practicable. If it isn’t the number of dwelling units on these two streets will have to be
reduced.
7. That the proposed number of residential units does not exceed the maximum number of
residential units. In staff’s eyes this matter is problematic. The applicant is counting a
substantial open space area as a part of this development in calculating the allowed
number of units, but an earlier approval required much of this area to be dedicated to the
city. If this open space area is excluded the number of allowed units would be decreased
from the proposal’s 234 (which should be 230) to no more than 151 units.
Staff recommends that the Planning Commission consider the matters raised above, make
appropriate findings in relation to the preliminary master plan, and direct staff to prepare findings,
conclusions, and a final order, and if the Commission elects to approve the plan it be approved
subject to the conditions of approval listed in Exhibit A.
Exhibits Following:
• Exhibit A – Draft Conditions of Approval
• Exhibit B – Application Materials
• Exhibit C – Trout Mountain Forestry Review
• Exhibit D – DKS Traffic Impact Analysis Review
• Exhibit E – Written Testimony submitted through September 9, 2014
GENERAL
1. These approval conditions shall be incorporated into deed restrictions and into covenants,
conditions and restrictions (C.C.&Rs). The approved conditions so incorporated into the
deed restrictions and C.C.&Rs are enforceable by the City, in a form approved by the city
attorney, and not subject to amendment, except as provided below, and shall be recorded
as an encumbrance with the title of the property in order that said conditions of approval
run with the land and are binding on all future owners/developers and land use decisions.
2. The proposed PUD shall not exceed a total of _____ dwelling units.
3. The proposed PUD shall contain no industrial or commercial uses other than home
occupations allowed by municipal code.
4. The approval of the preliminary master plan shall be effective for a period of two years
from ______________________, 2014, with automatic two-year extensions thereafter so
long as during the previous two-year period the applicant has submitted and received
approval of a final plat for one of the six phases identified in the preliminary master plan
dated February 2014.
5. Prior to submitting the first application for final master plan approval for a phase five
years after the city’s approval of the preliminary master plan, the applicant shall apply to
the planning commission for a re-evaluation of the unbuilt portions of the PUD for
conformity with the then-existing city ordinances, including but not limited to zoning,
subdivision, tree protection, and erosion control.
6. At the time of submitting the final plat for any phase, the applicant must demonstrate to
the satisfaction of the planning and community development director and the city
engineer that the phase is consistent with the preliminary master plan for the entire
project, the final master plan for the phase, and with all zoning, subdivision,
infrastructure, and related requirements (including but not limited to grading, erosion
control, and tree protection) then in effect.
7. At the time of application for approval of a final master plan for any phase after phase 1,
the applicant must have complied, to the extent possible, with all conditions of approval
for the development as a whole and for any previous phase.
ENVIRONMENTAL
8. Developer shall revise Phase 1 plans to preserve more large Sitka spruce trees.
9. The applicant shall contact the Oregon Department of Environmental Quality (DEQ) for
any necessary NPDES permits, and shall provide evidence of DEQ review and approval
of the erosion control aspects of the NPDES permit application materials to the city
engineer and to the Devils Lake Water Improvement District.
10. The owner/developer shall remove only those trees that are situated upon the phase being
developed at the time, and only as necessary for infrastructure improvements and/or to
allow reconnaissance surveys of the project site. In addition, tree removal shall be
subject to any applicable regulations regarding tree removal adopted by the City and in
effect at the time of the removal. Development shall not disturb vegetation except in
areas of building and structure envelopes, roadways, pedestrian paths, and utility line
corridors. Prior to removal of any trees, the applicant, subject to City review and
approval, shall prepare an approved tree protection plan.
11. The applicant shall prepare a tree protection plan for each phase of the development and
shall obtain approval of it from the planning and community development director and
the city engineer prior to applying for a tree cutting permit and before removing any
trees.
12. Pathways shall be permeable and shall be constructed of natural or recycled materials.
Where trail crossings over waterways are necessary, the crossing design shall minimize
the need for excavation, such as the use of wooden bridges rather than culverts, if
appropriate to minimize the need for excavation.
13. The project shall be subject to any site preparation regulations, in effect at the time of
development, adopted by the City.
14. No one shall burn openly within the PUD, either during construction or after completion
of construction.
15. Trees identified in the preliminary master plan for retention shall be marked in the field
and fenced prior to issuance of any construction permits. All fencing of trees to be
retained shall be maintained during all phases of construction. If, during construction, the
developer finds removing additional trees necessary, construction shall halt in the
immediate area of the subject tree(s) until the Planning and Community Development
Department and Public Works Department review and approve a revision to the tree
protection plan. Individual trees may be removed as part of construction of single-family
residences. In addition to recommendations outlined in the submitted arborists report (see
application material), steps for protection of retained trees must include the following:
a. Construction shall avoid injury to tree roots during onsite construction.
b. During dry periods, water shall be made available to the exposed roots of trees
subject to root loss.
c. All construction traffic shall be excluded from areas identified to remain as
undisturbed natural vegetation.
d. In lieu of adding soil around the base of a tree, a tree well with a diameter of four
feet greater than the tree diameter shall be installed.
e. Retaining walls or similar structures shall be provided to protect roots from
erosion.
f. In situations where trees are to be removed, the trees shall be cut (if possible),
rather than bulldozed or removed with similar procedures, in order to protect
soils, hillside integrity, and root structure of adjacent trees to be retained.
g. Trees that are to be retained, to serve as wind blocks for large trees planned for
retention, shall be identified.
16. All construction activities must be conducted in accordance with the City’s noise control
regulations as set out in the Lincoln City Municipal Code, including observing the quiet
hours of 7 PM to 7 AM.
17. Truck traffic in support of the development shall not occur after 7 PM or before 7 AM.
18. The applicant shall set up one or more wash-down areas for construction equipment to
avoid tracking dirt, mud, and gravel off the site. This condition is in addition to the
requirements of the City’s erosion control ordinance.
19. A detailed landscape plan shall be submitted with the final master plan(s) for review and
approval of staff, and shall include all common areas (including trail systems) and “open
space” within the subject property. The landscape plan shall comply with LCMC
17.52.100 and shall show and/or provide the following information:
a. Landscaping shall be provided for all areas of the project site where ground-
disturbing activities will occur, except for roads, sidewalk, parking areas, building
footprints, and above-ground infrastructure facilities.
b. Trees to be retained and tree protection measures shall be provided in accordance
with the approved tree protection plan.
c. Landscaping with suitable native tree plantings shall be adjacent to all retained
wetlands in order to provide shading and screening.
d. All mechanical equipment, including transformers shall be screened with
landscaping. Details of landscaping shall be provided.
e. All shrubs shall be provided in container sizes at a ratio of 3:1 (3-gallon
containers: 5-gallon containers).
f. Except as approved by the Planning and Community Development and Public
Works Departments, all trees must be planted at least ten feet away from any
public water, sewer, or storm drain lines. All trees must be installed with a
minimum of two support stakes. All nursery stakes must be removed from trees.
g. Wheel stops or curbs shall be provided along the outer boundaries of parking
areas or where landscaping may be damaged by vehicles.
h. A two-to-four inch layer of mulch must be applied in all landscape areas.
20. The PUD shall adhere to the tree preservation plan and landscape plan (including the
refinement plan to be submitted as part of final master plan approval) as outlined in the
application material and follow all recommendations and guidelines found in the
Arborist’s Report, dated November 1, 2005.
21. Final Covenant Conditions and Restrictions (CC&Rs) shall contain landscape
maintenance requirements including irrigation techniques to be used.
SURVEY
22. The county surveyor may require post monumentation of interior monuments. The
owner/developer shall discuss this issue with the county surveyor. In addition, any
survey monuments disturbed or destroyed during construction must be replaced and a
survey filed showing how the position of the monument was reestablished.
23. The location, dimensions and purpose of all proposed easements shall be shown on the
final PUD master plans and subdivision maps.
STORMWATER
1. The applicant shall submit two copies of a report of a registered professional engineer
licensed in Oregon identifying existing and proposed runoff flows from the site plus
two copies of engineering plans for proposed storm water detention, treatment, and
drainage features and facilities sufficient to accommodate the proposed runoff flows
according to generally accepted drainage accommodation principles, to the
Department of Public Works for review and approval either as submitted or as
modified in accord with requirements from the City Engineer. The City Engineer’s
review and any required modifications will be for the purpose of assuring that the
proposed features and facilities will be sufficient to accommodate the proposed runoff
flows according to generally accepted drainage accommodation principles, the City
Engineer’s considerations will include the Recommended Design Standards for Storm
water Facilities as set out in the attached Table 16 (at page 43) of the City’s Storm
Water Master Plan dated October 1993. The agreement shall require that the
applicant complete construction of the features and facilities in accord with the
approved engineering plans prior to occupancy of the initial development under the
site plan.
2. The storm water detention, treatment, and drainage features and facilities required
under Condition 1, above, shall include oil-water separator facilities or other
approved water quality control devices for the parking areas, as approved by the City
Engineer. The City Engineer’s review and any required modifications to the
engineering plans for such facilities or devices will be for the purpose of assuring that
the proposed facilities or devices will remove oil and similar wastes from the storm
water before the storm water leaves the site.
WATER
1. In the Final Order No. 07-22, the applicant was required to upgrade Port Lane water
booster station with, at a minimum, an on-site generator designed to provide
continued service for domestic and fire flows during power outage events. The
applicant did not enact this approval and consequently did not construct the upgrade
to Port Lane water booster station. However, in 2008/09 the City designed and
constructed this new booster station as part of a larger project - the Roads End
Reservoir Upgrade Project. The upgrade to the Port Lane booster pump station
improved service to existing customers and increased capacity for use by future
development. Since the Port Lane water booster station was designed and constructed
as part of a larger project, their associated cost was determined based on the actual
construction cost of the work directly associated with the booster pump station. The
cost associated with the Port Lane water booster station was determined to be
$578,521.00. The existing number of units or approved units served by the Port Lane
booster station is 457. The number of dwelling units in the pump service area that
could potentially served by the additional capacity booster pump station in addition to
Lincoln Palisades Phase 3 is146 (Logan Park @71 proposed, Rosso@50, Tribe@25).
The number of units for Phase 3 is 234. The total number of units potentially served
by the booster pump station is 837. Phase 3’s proportionate share of the water booster
pump stations is: $161,737.00. (Based on ($578,521.00) / 837 units = $691.18 per
unit and 234 units x $691.18 = $161,737.00.) Should the number units approved for
Phase 3 be modified, the actual number of units approved will be used to re-calculate
this fee.
SEWER
1. The applicant will be required to contribute toward the upgrade of the West Devils
Lake Road & Hwy 101 (WDLR) sanitary pump station. The dollar amount of
contribution will be based on a percentage of the flows contributed by the applicant
relative to the upgraded capacity of the station. The Pre-Design report prepared by
HBH Consulting Engineering dated April 17, 2014 was used to determine the
percentage of flow contributed by Phase 3, it was found that Phase 3 flows are 12.56
% of the full build out for the contributing area and was the basis of the WDLR Pump
Station Upgrade capacity. Therefore Lincoln Palisades is required to contribute
12.56% of the final engineering and construction cost of the WDLR Pump Station.
The final costs will be known once the project is complete, scheduled for February
2015. No additional flows will be allowed to be connected to the existing WDLR
until the Upgrade Project is completed and accepted by the City. While the City is
planning to move forward with this project, there are no guarantees until the Upgrade
Project is fully completed and in service. The fee will based on the following:
2.43 Capita per Equivalent Dwelling Unit (EDU)

(139 Single Family Residential) x (2.43) = 337.77 population
179.42 = 337.77 = 517.50 Phase 3 population

from NE Voyage to Logan Road, including overlay pavement, sidewalks or path,

2. The applicant shall be required to design the NE 47th Street Connector to the

STREET LIGHTS:
1. The location, design, style and type of street light pole and luminaire shall be
reviewed and approved by the City prior to final plat approval.
2. Street lights shall be provided by the owner/developer, located at street intersections
and the end of the cul-de-sacs, and spaced along the length of the streets at a
maximum distance of 220 feet. The energy and maintenance costs for each street light
shall be borne by the owner/developer and/or homeowners association.
PRIVATE UTILITIES:
1. The city subdivision ordinance requires that all utility lines shall be placed
underground throughout the subdivision.
2. All proposed easements shall be shown in dashed lines on the final plat, including the
size and location as required by the affected utilities, public agencies and utility
service companies.
3. All utility easement restrictions are to be recorded with the final plat.
4. All utility easements shall be clearly defined as to their scope, purpose and term,
preferably to be included within the restrictive covenants which are to be recorded
with the subdivision plat. The abbreviation “PUE” must be clearly defined and
spelled out.
5. A five (5) foot “PUE” adjacent to the rights-of-way shall be provided and be utilized
for water-related equipment (meters, valves, etc.) and other utilities (electrical
pedestals, street lights, telephone pairs, junction boxes, etc.).
6. It shall be the responsibility of the subdivider to coordinate final acceptance of all
proposed “PUEs” with affected utilities, public agencies and service companies prior
to final plat approval of the subdivision.
MAILBOXES:
1. The applicant shall coordinate with the U.S. Postal Service for the placement of
mailboxes located in Phase 3. In addition, mailboxes shall be located so that there
will be a minimum 5 foot clear space for the sidewalk.
BOND AND AGREEMENT:
1. The subdivider shall enter into a written agreement with the city, which agreement
will be subject to review and approval by the city attorney, that all required
improvement work as specified in the conditions of issuance of the development
permit shall be completed within twenty-four (24) months from final plat approval in
accordance with the city standards and applicable approved plans and specifications.
The subdivider shall warrant the materials and workmanship of the improvements for
a period of one (1) year from date of acceptance by the city.
2. Should the subdivider fail to complete the listed improvements within the specified
time period and/or in accordance with the terms of the agreement, the City may
complete the same and recover full cost and expense thereof from the subdivider.
3. The subdivider shall post one of the following with the improvement agreement to
ensure full and faithful performance:
• A surety bond executed by a surety company authorized to transact business
in the state of Oregon.
• Cash.
• An irrevocable standby letter of credit
GENERAL CONDITIONS
1. The final plat shall be in conformance with Title 16 (Subdivision Ordinance) and in
substantial conformance with the tentative subdivision plan as amended herein.
2. After the final plat has been approved by all city and county officials and recorded,
one reproducible four-mil mylar of all data (plat face, dedications, certificates,
approvals and one copy of recorded restrictive and protective covenants) shall be
returned to the city within thirty days of being recorded.
3. The applicant shall submit two copies of engineering plans for all improvements to
the Department of Public Works for review and approval either as submitted or as
modified in accordance with requirements of the City Engineer. The City Engineer’s
review and any required modifications shall be for the purpose of assuring that the
improvements shall be consistent with the provisions of this condition of approval.
4. The survey of the existing site topography shall include a minimum of 50’ beyond the
project boundary lines and use a registered city, county, or state brass cap monument
based on the NAVD 88 and NAV 82 for vertical and horizontal datum.
5. Within 30 days after construction is complete, the applicant shall submit survey-
verified as-built plans and electronic ACAD-compatible drawings in disk format for
the improvements, showing all changes from the approved plans made in the field by
the contractor. Information shown on the as-built plans shall include, but not be
limited to, all pipe invert elevations, materials, structure locations and elevations,
final grades of sidewalk, curb, gutter, and roadway improvements, and any other
structure or feature constructed under the site plan.
6. Applicant shall pay the actual cost incurred by the City for plan checking and
inspection of public works improvements that exceed an estimated construction cost
of $20,000. Applicant shall post a deposit with the City for the estimated inspection
fees prior to construction.
