Purpose [LCMC 17.52.210(A)]

text.i: It is the purpose of this section to allow master planned developments in any residential or
commercial zone, or any combination of them, and in doing so, to allow a more flexible
approach to land development than that which is normally accomplished through the
subdivision and zoning ordinances of the city. The planned unit development approach is
intended to provide more desirable environments by encouraging creative site planning and
building designs; to make possible greater diversification between buildings and open
spaces; and to conserve land and minimize development costs. In addition to the uses
allowed in residential zones, the planned unit development approach may allow certain
commercial uses subject to the specific limitations of this section.

page.text: Lincoln Palisades PUD
(“proposed PUD”) is a residential planned unit development at the
northern end of Lincoln City
(“City”). It is situated between Roads End and the Villages at
Cascade Head. NE Voyage Avenue provides access to the site.
A partnership group is the owner of the property doing business as Palisades Properties LLC
(“Owner”), as noted in the Lot Book Report issued by Western Title & Escrow Company (Exhibit
1). The same partnership group doing business as Alpha Building Ventures LLC is the
applicant.
The Owner’s development objectives include expanding the range of housing options
in this area while adding value through conservation reserves.
The 45.39-acre site is relatively flat across the northern end, and a steeply-banked drainage
dominates the southern end. The drainage would be designated as an open space that would
become a perpetual backyard amenity to many of the homes in the proposed PUD.
The design of the master plan recognizes that homes of various sizes are a building block of a
healthy, sustainable neighborhood. No commercial development is proposed. Instead there
would be three styles of homes: detached single-family homes, attached single-family homes,
and apartments. The attached homes would be configured at triplexes and 4-plexes. This
combination of housing types and sizes provides a range of opportunities for owner-occupancy
and rental.
This diversification could not be achieved were it not for the planned development provisions as
an alternative to a standard suburban-style subdivision.
Planning Commission Authority [LCMC 17.52.210(B)]

text.i: The planning commission shall have the authority to approve, approve with conditions, or
disapprove planned unit developments in any residential or commercial zone, or any
combination of them, subject to the provisions of this section.

page.text: Preliminary master plan documents have been submitted for consideration by the Planning
Commission and a decision based on the review criteria set forth in LCMC 17.52.210(L) and
(Q), respectively.

Pre-Application Conference [LCMC 17.52.210(C)]

text.i: Prior to filing an application for a planned unit development, the applicant shall review the
applicant’s preliminary master plan with the city manager or the city manager’s designated
representative at a pre-application conference. The purpose of the pre-application
conference is to inform the city of the nature of a likely PUD application at an early date and
to provide the potential applicant with information on what will be needed to make an
application complete.

page.text: A pre-application conference was held on February 13, 2013.

Maximum number of units for the 45.39-acre subject property, based on the maximum

Actual number of units in the proposed PUD.

The gross square footage of the project site was determined by survey. The area of delineated
wetlands as derived by survey as referenced in the wetland delineation report (Exhibit 2).

text.i: Determine the gross square footage of the project site.
Subtract from the gross square footage the square footage of
any areas proposed for nonresidential development,
including commercial uses, churches, schools, and public
buildings and their associated parking areas and grounds
(including required yards and landscaping areas). The result
is the “preliminary gross residential area.”
Subtract from the preliminary gross residential area the
square footage of any areas of significant natural resources
as identified in the comprehensive plan. The result is the
“final gross residential area.”
Multiply the final gross residential area by 0.83. The result is
the “final net residential area.”
Divide the final net residential area by the minimum lot size of
the underlying zone. The result is the “Maximum Base
Residential Density” expressed in dwelling units. Any number
not a whole number shall be rounded down to a whole
number.

a. Floodplain [

text.i: i. Requirement. For projects where part(s) of the site is located within the 100-year
floodplain as defined and mapped by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, the
portions in the floodplain must be developed according to the National Flood Insurance
Program requirements.
ii. Density Bonus Standard. For projects where part(s) of the site is located within the 100-
year floodplain as defined and mapped by the Federal Emergency Management Agency,
develop only on portions of the site that are not in the 100-year floodplain or on portions that
have been previously developed. (0.01 point.)

page.text: Computation: This bonus does not apply because no portion of the subject property is located
within the 100-year floodplain as depicted on the Flood Insurance Rate Map 41041C0040D,
effective December 18, 2009. No credit is claimed for this density bonus.
b. Steep Slopes [

text.i: i. Requirement. On portions of the project site with pre-project slopes greater than 15
percent that are not previously developed, do not disturb slopes greater than 40 percent and
do not disturb portions of the project site within 50 feet of the top of such slopes, and 75 feet
from the toe of such slopes.
ii. Density Bonus Standard. On portions of the project site with pre-project slopes greater
than 15 percent that are not previously developed sites, limit development to no more than
40 percent of slopes between 25 percent and 40 percent, and to no more than 60 percent of
slopes between 15 percent and 25 percent, and locate development such that the
percentage of the development footprint that is on pre-project slopes less than 15 percent is
greater than the project’s total percentage of buildable land that has pre-project slopes less
than 15 percent. (0.01 point.)

page.text: Computation: This bonus standard has three qualifiers that compare a slope analysis of the
undisturbed site with the proposed development plan. All three qualifiers must be met to earn
the density bonus of one percent. Table 3 presents a summary of the slope analysis for the site.

The development plan was then overlaid on the slope analysis to determine what percent of
each slope range would be developed. The first two qualifiers for this density bonus set limits on
the amount of development in two slope ranges. Table 4 demonstrates how the proposed
development plan complies with the first two qualifiers.

text.b: Table 4, Percentage of Slope to be Developed

page.text: The third qualifier pertains to the size of the development footprint on slopes less than 15
percent. Having met the first two qualifiers, the density bonus is awarded if a disproportionate
share of the building footprint is situated away from steeper slopes. Table 5 shows that 41.7% of
the total building footprint would be developed on 33.3% of the site where slopes are less than
15 percent. Therefore the proposed PUD qualifies for a one percent density bonus, or two
additional units.

page.text: Computation:
The “Local Wetlands Inventory for the City of Lincoln City” (SRI/Shapiro, 1996)
mapped a 4.84-acre continuous wetland along the channels on the subject property. This
wetland was designated DEL-33 on the LWI. This wetland was deemed significant, in part, due
to the presence of the Northern red-legged frog observed in DEL-
33. As noted in “Determination
of Significant Wetlands” (SRI/Shapiro, page 7), “These wetlands were accepted by the CAC as
satisfying the criteria for inclusion as habitat for RTE [Rare, Threatened, Endangered] and
sensitive species.” The Northern red-legged frog is listed as a “species of concern” by the U.S.
Fish and Wildlife Service and “sensitive – vulnerable species” by the Oregon Department of Fish
& Wildlife. However this species is known to move as far as 1-2 kilometers into terrestrial habitat
for a substantial portion of the non-breeding season
. Given the geographic extent of these
habitat needs, no credit is claimed for this density bonus.

text.i: i. Requirement. Design streets so that pullouts and public transit shelters may be added in
the future without the need to acquire additional rights-of-way or relocate any sidewalks or
utility lines.

shelters, adequate to buffer wind and rain, at appropriate locations within the project
boundaries. If public transit does not serve the area of the project, provide pullouts at
appropriate locations within the project boundaries so that public transit shelters may be
added in the future. (0.01 point.)

Fair Housing Amendments Act (FHAA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act
(Rehabilitation Act), as applicable. Separate residential unit types include: single-family,

project shall comply with the accessible design provisions of the FHAA and Rehabilitation
Act, as applicable; and facilities and rights-of-way shall comply with the accessible design

f.
Energy Efficiency [

text.i: i. Requirement. None.
ii. Density Bonus Standard. (0.02 point).
(A) For new residential structures of three stories or fewer, build and equip the structures to
qualify as an Energy Star Home by either a performance path (through a HERS Index
rating) or a prescriptive path (Building Option Package or BOP); and
(B) For nonresidential structures and residential structures of more than three stories,
demonstrate a minimum 10 percent improvement in the proposed building performance
rating compared to the baseline building performance rating per ASHRAE/IESNA Standard
90.1-2007 (without addenda) by a whole building project simulation using the Building
Performance Rating Method in Appendix G of the Standard. Appendix G requires that this
energy analysis include all of the energy costs within and associated with the building
project. The proposed design must comply with the mandatory provisions (Sections 5.4, 6.4,
7.4, 8.4, 9.4 and 10.4) in Standard 90.1-2007 (without addenda), must include all the energy
costs within and associated with the building project, and must be compared against a
baseline building that complies with Appendix G to Standard 90.1-2007 (without addenda).
The default process energy cost is 25 percent of the total energy cost for the baseline
building. For buildings where the process energy cost is less than 25 percent of the baseline
building energy cost, the applicant must provide supporting documentation substantiating
that process energy inputs are appropriate. For the purposes of this analysis, process
energy is considered to include, but is not limited to, office and general miscellaneous
equipment, computers, elevators and escalators, kitchen cooking and refrigeration, laundry
washing and drying, lighting exempt from the lighting power allowance (e.g., lighting integral
to medical equipment) and other (e.g., waterfall pumps). Regulated (nonprocess) energy
includes lighting (such as for the interior, parking garage, surface parking, facade, or
building grounds, except as noted above), HVAC (such as for space heating, space cooling,
fans, pumps, toilet exhaust, parking garage ventilation, kitchen hood exhaust, etc.) and
service water heating for domestic or space heating purposes.

page.text: Computation: The proposed units would be constructed following the prescriptive path for
Energy Star homes as set forth in the Building Option Package as required by subsection (A).
Subsection (B) does not apply because no nonresidential structures or residential structures of
more than three stories are proposed. Therefore the proposed PUD qualifies for a two percent
density bonus, or four additional units.

text.i: i. Requirement. For irrigation, design and install all irrigation systems in the project so that

such as roads, driveways, parking lots, and sidewalks.

h. Indoor Water Conservation [

text.i: i. Requirement. None.
ii. Density Bonus Standard. Design and construct at least 90 percent of all buildings in the
project such that they meet one of the following requirements according to the appropriate
category (0.01 point):
(A) For nonresidential buildings and residential buildings over three stories, employ
strategies that in aggregate use 30 percent less water than the water use baseline
calculated for the building (not including irrigation) after meeting the Energy Policy Act of
1992 fixture performance requirements. Calculations are based on estimated occupant
usage and shall include only the following fixtures (as applicable to the building): water
closets, urinals, lavatory faucets, showers, and kitchen faucets.
(B) For residential buildings three stories or fewer, install fixtures that comply with all of the
following requirements:
(1) The average flow rate for all lavatory faucets must be no more than 2.0 gpm.
(2) The average flow rate for all shower heads must be no more than 2.0 gpm.
(3) The average flow rate for all toilets, including dual-flush toilets, must be no more than 1.3
gpm.

page.text: Computation: Subsection (A) does not apply because there would be no nonresidential
buildings or residential buildings over three stories. All fixtures would comply with the flow rate
limitations in Subsection (B). Therefore the proposed PUD qualifies for a one percent density
bonus, or two additional units.

In all, 24.76 acres, or 54 percent of the site, would remain under the existing tree canopy. To
qualify for the density bonus, 34 percent of the tree canopy in developable areas would be
preserved and incorporated in the proposed PUD. Therefore the proposed PUD qualifies for the
maximum ten percent density bonus, or twenty additional units.
j.
Affordable Housing [

text.i: An additional density bonus of 10 percent above the maximum base residential density shall
be available for projects incorporating an affordable housing element. For the purposes of
this section an affordable housing element must include the following components:
1. At least five percent of the total number of dwelling units in the project must be
affordable units.
2. The affordable units must be incorporated into the overall project and not be clustered
into a separate area of the project. This provision is not intended to prohibit “cottage
clusters” of affordable units; provided, that such clusters are themselves incorporated into
the overall project and not clustered into a separate area of the project.
To be considered “affordable” a unit must meet affordability standards as adopted by the
city. Alternatively the developer may transfer title to individual lots dedicated to affordable
housing to the Lincoln County Land Trust or other organization approved by the planning
and community development director for development by that entity as affordable housing.

page.text: Computation: This density bonus does not apply because all units would be market rate
housing. No credit is claimed for this density bonus.

restrictions; specifically which restrictions, if any, are proposed to be enforceable by the
city; the time at which the restrictions will become enforceable; and which restrictions, if
any, will not be subject to amendment without the consent of the city.

page.text: The layout of the proposed PUD relies on the existing street system to provide access to each
phase of the PUD. NE Voyage Avenue extends from NE Devils Lake Boulevard on the south
through Lincoln Palisades to NE Devils Lake Boulevard on the north in Rock Creek Village,
although a short segment on the north end is not constructed. NE Voyage Avenue is a 36-foot
paved street with curbs and gutters on both sides within a 50-foot right-of-way.
NE Voyage Loop and NE Wave Lane were constructed for Lincoln Palisades Phase 2. At the
same time, segments of NE 51
st
Lane and 55
th
Place were constructed. These streets have a
28-foot paved surface with curb, gutters, and curbside sidewalks on both sides and would
provide access to the proposed PUD.
The stub for 51
st
Loop near the southwest corner would not be extended in the PUD because
the slope is too steep for a perpendicular intersection. Rather, NE Crest Court follows the grade
to provide access to Phase 4 lots.
The existing street pattern would be extended into the subject property to provide access to the
proposed PUD. Locations, grades, and typical sections of each street, as well as the location
and size of utility mains, are shown on the preliminary master plan. Table 8 summarizes the
characteristics of each street.

text.i: 3. Approximate plan of proposed sanitary sewers, storm drains, storm water detention and
drainage pretreatment facilities and the water distribution system.

page.text: Lincoln Palisades PUD would be served by municipal water, wastewater, and storm drainage
facilities operated by the City. The proposed plan for these utilities is shown on the preliminary
master plan.
An existing 8-inch water main in NE Voyage Avenue would be extended along the proposed
street network to provide service connections to each dwelling in the PUD. New mains would be
looped as appropriate for fire suppression purposes. Fire hydrants would be spaced according
to fire code and City standards to provide maximum coverage.
In Phases 1 and 5 where homes cannot be served without a sewage pump station, an E/One
Sewer system would be installed. For this system, a grinder pump station collects the
wastewater from the apartment building or home and grinds it into slurry. The wastewater is
then pumped through a private small-diameter pipe to
the City’s gravity main. Other phases
would be served by a gravity collection system that terminates at a sewage pump station of NE
Devils Lake Boulevard. This pump station is currently operating near capacity. The applicant is
willing to pay a fair share to increase the capacity of the pump station.
Phase 1 stormwater would be collected, pre-treated, and stored on-site, then discharged at pre-
development rates to the existing surface drainage system. For all other phases, a gravity
system would collect stormwater for localized pre-treatment and storage before discharge at
pre-development rates to the creek on the east side of the subject property.

text.i: 4. A general description of property intended to be dedicated to the city or public, other
than street rights-of-way, including proposed dedication restrictions.

page.text: The applicant proposes to grant to the public approximately 19.49 acres of open space, referred
to as Tracts A and B on the preliminary master plan. These tracts include the creek and several
minor tributaries on the east side of the subject property. No restrictions are proposed.

text.i: 5. A description of any residential density bonus the applicant is requesting, including
evidence demonstrating compliance with applicable density bonus standards.

page.text: The applicant requests residential density bonuses totaling 30 units. Reference is made to the
findings and conclusions addressing the applicable standards set forth in LCMC 17.52.210(D)-
(F) beginning on page 2. Those findings and conclusions are hereby incorporated by reference
to demonstrate compliance with this criterion.

text.i: 6. Proposed number of residential units.

page.text: The proposed number of dwelling units in Lincoln Palisades PUD is 234.

text.i: 8. A narrative description of the planned unit development and the manner in which it
meets the purpose set out in subsection (A) of this section.

page.text: A statement describing the proposed PUD and how it conforms to the purpose statement for a
PUD is found on page 2 under LCMC 17.52.210(A). That narrative is incorporated herein by
reference as complying with this criterion.

text.i: 9. A statement describing the present and proposed ownership.

page.text: The undeveloped property is currently owned by Alpha Business Ventures LLC, who is the
applicant for Lincoln Palisades PUD. This entity would continue to own the property through the
entitlement process. Lots would be sold for development by others.

text.i: 10. A preliminary landscape plan, covering both areas to retain undisturbed their natural
vegetation and areas to be re-landscaped.

page.text: The preliminary landscape plan is attached to the preliminary master plan. Approximately 54
percent of the site would remain undisturbed with the existing tree canopy intact. Ground
disturbance would be the minimal necessary to grade streets and building pads and install
utilities. Once construction is complete, those areas would be landscaped. The proposed
landscape plan makes use of native species of trees, shrubs, and groundcover recommended
by the City’s
Guide to Landscape Selections.

text.i: 11. A circulation plan and traffic impact analysis identifying likely circulation patterns for and
traffic impacts from traffic generated by the development including patterns and impacts
within the development, in the area surrounding the development, and in other affected
areas of the city.

page.text: Lincoln Palisades PUD
Reece
a
ssociates, inc.
Page 14
Access Engineering
(“Access”) prepared an analysis of off-site traffic impacts (Exhibit 4). A total
of 198 PM peak hour trips would be generated by the proposed PUD when fully developed.
Table 3 in that study summarizes the conditions of area streets that would experience increased
traffic from the proposed PUD. NE Voyage Avenue, NE 47
th
Street, NE West Devils Lake Road,
and NE Logan Rogan south of NE 50
th
Street are full-width City streets, constructed to City
standards. As constructed, these streets are intended to accommodate traffic at full build out of
the urbanizable area. These streets are in good repair. NE Port Lane and NE Logan Road north
of NE 50
th
Street are characterized as rural roads with a paved lane in each direction without
urban features such as curbs, gutters, and sidewalks, but nonetheless capable of
accommodating the increased traffic. According to the Access report (page 9)
, “Due to the
unimproved condition of Port Lane, this route will be primarily used for access to the shopping
and recreational areas on Logan Road.” Therefore, no improvements to these streets are
warranted to accommodate traffic generated by the proposed PUD.
At a greater distance from the proposed PUD, the Access report found that the intersection of
Highway 101 and NE Logan Road would not exceed the ODOT mobility standard at the
completion of Phase 6 in 2025. However, the Highway 101 intersection at NE West Devils Lake
Road would exceed the ODOT mobility standard in Phase 4. Two projects in the Transportation
Master Plan and the TSP Update would ameliorate traffic impacts and would enable Phases 4-6
to be completed without exceeding the ODOT mobility standard. Those projects are:
Project 13-B provides widening Highway 101 to five lanes from NE Logan Road through
the NE West Devils Lake Road intersection.
Project 14-B provides for doubling the northeast bound Highway 101 left turn lane at NE
Logan Road and changes the movements allowed on the middle southwest bound
approaches on NE Logan Road.
Highway 101 is a state highway maintained by the Oregon Department of Transportation
(ODOT). ODOT budgets for highway improvements through the Oregon Statewide
Transportation Improvement Program (STIP). The STIP is Oregon’s adopted four-year
investment program for major state and regional transportation systems. It covers all major
transportation projects for which funding is approved and that are expected to be built during a
four-year time frame. The current STIP lists projects for the period 2012-2015. City Projects 13-
B and 14-B described above are state highway improvements that would be eligible for funding
under the STIP as improvements to a state highway but they are not included in the 2012-2015
STIP. If included in a future STIP, the state would determine when the projects are constructed.
For example, construction is scheduled to begin in 2013 for a $12.6M Highway 101 project in
Lincoln City between SE 16
th
and SE 36
th
Streets.
Design for that project began in 2007 under
a previous STIP.
The Access report concluded that City Projects 13-B and 14-B would have to be built to improve
mobility of Highway 101 in order to mitigate build out of the proposed PUD. Typically such state
highway projects are funded through ODOT’s STIP program. In the event City Projects 13-B
and 14-B are not constructed in time to mitigate the traffic impact of Phases 4-6, it would be
